passages: [B] In July 751, Gao Xianzhi, a Tang Dynasty general of Goguryeo origin, led his troops and fought against Islamic forces near the Talas River in present-day Kazakhstan, suffering a major defeat. At this time, tens of thousands of Tang soldiers were captured as prisoners, including papermaking technicians. Thus, the Battle of Talas became a direct catalyst for the spread of Chinese papermaking technology to the Islamic world. For the Middle Eastern region, which had mainly used parchment made from dried and beaten sheepskin, this was the appearance of an amazing new product. With the introduction of papermaking technology, the literature and scholarship of the Islamic Empire developed greatly.

[C] English, a Germanic language like German, took a completely different attitude toward loanwords and foreign words than German did. English, which had already widely accepted Latin words since the Old English period, was deeply infiltrated by French after William of Normandy's conquest of England in 1066. The ruling class used only French, and English was the 'lowly' language of the ruled class, but even in that lowly language, the language of the ruling class was transfused, and the proportion of French/Latin series in the English vocabulary gradually increased. If two important events had not occurred, English would probably have been suppressed by French and disappeared even from English territory. The first of these events was England's loss of Normandy territory in 1204. This meant that the English royal family lost their homeland in the French-speaking region of continental Europe to the French king, severing the territorial connection between England and the French-speaking world. The second event was the Hundred Years' War, which lasted from 1337 to 1453. This war aroused English patriotism and stirred attachment to English, the 'lowly language.' During the Hundred Years' War, in the mid-14th century, English regained its status as an official language, but this Middle English was a language in which at least half of its vocabulary had become Old French.
However, the English did not try to reject the French that had deeply penetrated their language. The fact that French was still used in parts of the court and in the courts even after English became the official language was also a reason for this tolerance. It was not until the 18th century that English courts abandoned French and adopted English. In other words, English and French cohabited on English soil for nearly 700 years. Thus, after regaining its status as an official language in England, English continuously received new words from French. These words covered the entire superstructure, including politics, law, administration, art, science, and religion. Among English words today, relatively sophisticated words generally come from French.
English has never shown resistance to any foreign words, not just French or classical European languages. Even when England was the center of English, English already contained words originating from every corner of the world, and American English, which became the new center of English in the 20th century, had already borrowed much vocabulary from Native American languages for hundreds of years. That was truly fortunate for English. The rich vocabulary absorbed into English from numerous languages created subtle textures in this language and greatly contributed to the development and refinement of English.

[E] To understand Gulf society, it is essential to understand the family that forms the foundation of society and the women who stand at the center of the family. This is because women are at the center of the conservatism and closedness that distinguish Gulf society from other societies. Although there are some differences by country, Gulf society embodies the symbol of social, cultural, and religious orthodoxy through control over the foundation of society—the family, that is, women. Women are socially isolated and forced to perform only limited roles within the home, and their freedom of movement is also restricted. Not only foreign travel but also domestic travel requires the consent or accompaniment of a guardian. Family law based on Islamic Sharia law gives men absolute authority in marriage and divorce, and women have very limited room to choose their own fate in matters of marriage or divorce. The distinction between men and women limits women's right to education and choices, and the social participation of educated women is restricted to limited fields such as education and health.
However, the spread of new media following the development of information and communication technology (ICT) in the era of globalization shows the potential to serve as a catalyst for social change in the Gulf region. Traditionally, Gulf states have controlled media through strict pre-censorship to block content that threatens the system or goes against Islamic values. However, such censorship and control have instead aroused people's desire for uncensored new media, and the state's control over new media has inevitably weakened due to the technical characteristics of new media. Among various new media, primarily one-to-many satellite broadcasting has become a breakthrough for people in the Gulf region to escape from a 'closed society' and look into an 'open society,' and secondarily, many-to-many internet has penetrated deeply into the younger generation of Gulf society, including women, heralding changes in Gulf society.

[F] The origin of dance and song on the Korean Peninsula can be found in records of ancient society's rituals to heaven, where many men and women gathered to drink, dance, and sing together. The aspects of ancient festivals can be inferred today through shamanistic rituals such as fishing festivals and communal exorcisms, and through shamans. Shamans who sing the will of gods and human prayers through instruments and shamanistic songs, and express the appearance of gods and various human affairs through dance and gestures, can be seen as the vanguard of Korean performing arts and ancestors of Hallyu, in that they are performers, singers, and dancers. Meanwhile, as society developed, professional entertainers such as gisaeng and singers emerged in response to the general public's demand to appreciate entertainers' skills at entertainment venues. Representative examples include the gisaeng Hwang Jin-i and the fictional character Gang Nam-hong created by writer Nam Young-ro, who serve as exemplars and model aspirations for Hallyu as ideal female entertainers perfectly equipped with talents in dance, song, and literature. In that parts that would be spoken are enumerated to rhythm, pop rap and pansori's aniri are similar. The characteristic of Korean pop that recites 4.4-meter 2-foot repetitive rhythm at a fast tempo can find similar characteristics in pansori's jajinmori and hwimori rhythms. Also, the singing method that weaves lyrics at a fast tempo shows similar function and rhythm to pop rap in the folk tradition of woven narrative songs that weave long lyrics that have become comedic and lengthy at fast speed.

[G] On the 3rd, the government announced the 'Youth Employment Activation Measures' at the Government Complex Seoul, expanding youth employment support to 1.04 million people. As youth unemployment became severe due to the COVID-19 crisis, the Ministry of Employment and Labor issued special response measures jointly with related ministries including the Ministry of Economy and Finance and the Ministry of Education. As a result, the government's youth employment support scale this year increased by 246,000 from the original 794,000, and the related budget also increased from 4.4 trillion won to 5.9 trillion won. As society becomes unstable when youth unemployment increases, resolution measures are urgent. Young people are frustrated by employment opportunities that have narrowed further due to COVID-19. The number of young employed last year decreased by 183,000 compared to 2019. The perceived unemployment rate also increased to 25.1%. As the COVID-19 crisis prolonged, companies and service businesses reduced hiring citing economic recession. Among them, youth jobs decreased sharply. The delay in young people's entry into the labor market and loss of work experience due to rising youth unemployment can have lasting negative effects on young people and ultimately act as a negative factor for economic development. This government measure focuses on expanding private jobs for young people through corporate support. As the possibility of early economic recovery is not high, it is difficult to expect dramatic employment improvement in the private sector, so the government has no choice but to provide special support. As a result, the target of the 'Youth Digital Jobs Project' will increase from 50,000 to 110,000. To induce new youth hiring by small and medium enterprises, 20,000 of the 50,000 'Special Employment Promotion Incentive' targets will be preferentially supported for young people. The government should spare no support so that private companies can hire more young people.

[H] Just as we help poor neighbors, it is natural for developed countries in the global village to help poor countries. It is in the same context that the Development Assistance Committee (OECD DAC) of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, composed of developed countries, operates and supports Official Development Assistance (ODA) programs for economic development and poverty elimination in poor countries. Of course, our country also provides aid to many countries both paid and unpaid through the Ministry of Economy and Finance, Korea Eximbank, Economic Development Cooperation Fund (EDCF Korea), Korea International Cooperation Agency (KOICA), and non-governmental organizations (NGOs).
The problem is the dilemma of aid. The saying that good intentions do not necessarily lead to good results also applies to aid. For example, aid to Africa raises doubts about 'whether aid has really been helpful at all.' Dambisa Moyo, an economist from Zambia in south-central Africa, said, "Aid doesn't help. It didn't in the past and won't in the future. In fact, aid itself is the problem." Moyo's 'aid pessimism' is related to the corrupt structure of aid. Most aid is given and received between governments. The political structure of underdeveloped countries such as Africa is dictatorial. Whether free or paid, when support goes through the government, a considerable amount of aid is diverted to the dictator's personal property. Such corruption occurs in a chain reaction at the lower levels where aid is implemented, preventing aid from being used for economic development or progress. Raghuram Rajan and Arvind Subramanian of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) also released research findings stating, "We found no evidence that any kind of aid triggered national economic growth."
The example they gave was Zambia. Since 1960, the aid Zambia received has continuously increased, but during the same period, the growth rate actually plummeted. Aid also acts as a factor that incites extreme political strife between political forces over aid benefits. In poor countries without political stability, aid represents significant interests. Political conflicts over interests inevitably deteriorate into 'all or nothing' games. There are also criticisms that aid does not encourage entrepreneurship. For example, when many products pour in through free aid, the domestic product market that was trading in the market, albeit insufficiently, dies. It is said that if our country provides North Korea with various products, medicine, clothing, and food for free, even the formed North Korean markets will close. There's no way trade can happen when free supplies are pouring in. Angus Deaton, a Nobel Prize winner in Economics, pointed out that "charitable aid reduces efforts to improve one's life on one's own."

Humanities/Social Science.question: [B], [C], [E] have similar viewpoints and you support this viewpoint. Describe the reasons and evaluate [F], [G], [H] from that viewpoint.
reference_answer:
Among the two perspectives on patterns of development above, I support the viewpoint of [B], [C], [E]. This is because external help is often essential for development, and external help generally does more good than harm for development.
Based on this, evaluating Passages [F], [G], [H] is as follows. [F] argues that the origin of Hallyu such as Korean pop lies in folk traditions such as ancient heavenly rituals or pansori. [F] contrasts with the viewpoint of [B], [C], [E]. From the viewpoint of [B], [C], [E], [F] can be criticized in that Hallyu might have developed further if there had been external contact or external help. [G] is a case where the government's special support policy brings about resolution of youth unemployment problems and increased youth employment when dramatic employment improvement in the private sector cannot be expected, so it aligns with the viewpoint of [B], [C], [E] that external (government) help is often essential for improving situations. [H] points out that while it is natural for developed countries to help poor countries, aid cannot encourage entrepreneurship and can reduce efforts to improve life on one's own, and moreover does not lead to development. From the viewpoint of [B], [C], [E], [H] is a case of a state where there is no development despite external help, so it can be said to raise questions about the viewpoint of [B], [C], [E].

passages:
<Passage 1> The general requirements for cooperation are twofold. First, cooperation is based on reciprocity. Second, there must be a belief that reciprocity can be stably maintained over a long period. Ultimately, cooperation is possible when both parties can help each other. However, if there is a cost to helping, a dilemma may arise. From the perspective of the cooperating parties, the benefit gained from the other's cooperation must be greater than the cost I incur when cooperating, in order for there to be a reason to cooperate and realize the opportunity for mutual benefit. In this case, it's natural that all cooperating parties would prefer mutual cooperation over mutual betrayal. However, getting what I want isn't easy for two reasons. First, it's more beneficial for me not to help in the short term, yet the other party still wants to induce me to help them. Second, I feel tempted to receive all possible help without providing help that costs me greatly. Nevertheless, once cooperation based on reciprocity takes root within a group, any non-cooperative strategy becomes difficult to penetrate, allowing it to protect itself.
It's very encouraging that cooperation can emerge, flourish even in environments with all sorts of diverse strategies mixed together, and protect itself once established. But what's most interesting is that the characteristics of individuals or social environments have little impact on achieving these results. Individuals don't need to be logical or understand how and why they should act in certain ways. The evolutionary process naturally allows successful strategies to flourish. Also, individuals don't need to exchange messages or promises. Words aren't necessary because actions speak instead. Similarly, no trust between individuals is needed because reciprocity alone can make betrayal unproductive. Altruism isn't necessary either because successful strategies can elicit cooperation even from selfish individuals.
There are a few assumptions about individuals and social environments that are essential for the emergence, growth, and maintenance of cooperation. First, one must be able to recognize cooperators from previous interactions and remember the history of past interactions with others. This allows for appropriate responses. However, in reality, meeting the requirements of recognition and memory isn't that difficult. Even bacteria satisfy these requirements by either interacting with only a single partner or responding only to the most recent action of the other party with a single strategy. If bacteria can do it, humans can too.

<Passage 2> We should make the best use of the power of competition as a means of coordinating human efforts. This is based on the conviction that where effective competition can be created, it is a better guide to individual efforts than any other method. I don't deny that for competition to operate beneficially, a carefully designed legal framework is needed. Nor do I deny that if conditions for effective competition are difficult to satisfy, other methods should guide economic activity. However, I oppose the substitution of competition with inferior methods for coordinating individual efforts.
I consider competition to be a superior method not only because it is the most efficient of known methods, but more importantly because it is the only method that can coordinate our actions without the coercive and arbitrary interference of authority. In fact, one of the key reasons for preferring competition is that it doesn't require conscious social control, and it gives everyone the opportunity to judge for themselves whether a particular occupation has enough prospects to offset its disadvantages and risks. While coercive interference must be excluded to utilize competition well as a principle of social organization, certain types of interference that can assist its operation are acceptable, and government measures may be necessary in some cases. However, it must be especially emphasized that coercive force should not be used. Market participants should be free to buy and sell at any price if they can find a trading partner, and anyone should be freely able to produce, sell, and buy anything that can be sold.
It is fundamentally important to allow free entry to all occupations under the same conditions for everyone. It is equally fundamentally important that the law not tolerate attempts by individuals or groups to restrict such entry using overt or hidden power. If prices or quantities of specific goods are controlled, competition's ability to effectively coordinate individual efforts is taken away. This is because changes in prices would no longer reflect all changed circumstances, and as a result, price changes could no longer serve as a reliable guide to individual behavior.

<Passage 3> Common resources such as forests and seas, which are jointly owned by all members of society, have no excludability but do have rivalry. Because there is no excludability, anyone can consume the common resource without paying, but because there is rivalry, when someone consumes the common resource, others' consumption opportunities decrease. Therefore, we compete to consume more common resources before others do. Due to these characteristics, common resources are easily abused, consumed excessively beyond necessary amounts, and have a high possibility of depletion. Regarding this, some communitarians argue that community-based solutions are the most natural solutions fitting human nature. For them, nature is not an arena of survival competition described as "survival of the fittest" or "teeth and claws red with blood." Rather, they argue that the feeling of mutual aid has been cultivated through hundreds of thousands of years of group living and thousands of years of social life, and that "unless people are going crazy as on a battlefield," the feeling of mutual aid is an law that cannot be resisted.
However, humans are not always prepared to act for the public good. Therefore, we cannot rely solely on human nature and need appropriate incentives and institutions. This is because under appropriate institutions, one can harmonize self-interest with common interest. The appropriate institution here is not a mechanism that externally and top-down forces individuals pursuing material gain, but a check mechanism that can regulate each other through mutual trust. This is possible because humans are beings who respond with cooperation whenever the will of the other party to cooperate is confirmed, consider the impact of their actions on others, and have the intention to step forward as if it were their own affair to control it when someone else's action harms others.
In the 1960s, fishermen in a lobster-catching area in Australia faced the problem of continuously decreasing lobster numbers. To solve the problem, the fishermen came up with a good idea: forming a community and limiting the number of nets that could be installed. As people started monitoring others installing additional nets, those illegally installing nets disappeared, and eventually, they succeeded in increasing the number of lobsters. If the government had unilaterally restricted nets, illegal fishing would have flourished, as it did in many countries, with some fishermen secretly catching lobsters without restriction and cutting their nets to escape patrol boats when they approached. However, with fishermen autonomously imposing restrictions, illegal fishing naturally disappeared.
Some people view the idea of maintaining social order based on community as an outdated ideology, while others see it as a utopian ideology. However, in many cases, community members mutually monitoring and sanctioning each other becomes an effective way to manage common resources. This is because community members possess information that external authorities do not have, and within the community, they can avoid tragedy by regulating each other based on mutual trust.

<Passage 4> While competition allows each person's abilities to be maximized, it's true that those who lose in competition suffer various side effects. This is because competition is essentially 'cold.' Therefore, in the market, we can see paradoxical cases where two competing companies temporarily cooperate or partially introduce various forms of cooperation into competition to avoid losing. For example, after competing for a long time, a company may temporarily change its position to become a cooperative supplier providing parts to a competitor. Cooperation can also change the form of competition to be indirect. For instance, one company may form independent partnerships with two other companies, creating a structure where the partner companies compete with each other. There can also be partial cooperation in ways such as competing in sales but provisionally cooperating in research and development, or even dividing departments so that some departments cooperate while others compete. Cooperation with competitors especially occurs when new technologies emerge and technological or industrial convergence happens, or when a company is small and needs to enhance its competitiveness. Nevertheless, the competition mechanism fundamentally induces companies to focus more on innovation to secure a competitive advantage. This is because companies generally have more incentive to invest in innovation activities such as research and development in competitive situations rather than monopolistic ones.
From a societal perspective, as competition intensifies, others in social contact will be regarded only as actual or potential competitors, and when this thinking prevails, it becomes difficult to maintain social affinity based on humanism. Therefore, economic thinkers have often pointed out that while competition contributes to increasing national wealth, it erodes social homogeneity and morality. Considering these issues, the challenge that arises is setting a 'golden mean' that continues to utilize the functions of competition on one hand while weakening the inhumane aspects it causes on the other. The social market economy system introduced by Germany and several Western countries after World War II was formed against this background. The aim was to minimize the coldness and socio-economic dysfunction inherent in capitalist society while basing it on the functions of a market economy that increases efficiency.
Recently, it's easy to find countries declaring they will harmonize stability and equity or quality of life by modifying past growth-first policies. For this, above all, consensus on the basic values of society must be formed. Otherwise, various conflicts that emerge risk going beyond society's control capabilities. This is why the participation of all social members or interest groups is needed in discussions to establish norms that don't damage progress through fair competition as a principle of coexistence, yet harmonize with the existence of social life based on humanism. The various desires, opinions, and claims explosively erupting recently are perhaps the inevitable growing pains of forming a social consensus for creating a new order.

Humanities/Social Science.question: <Passages 1> to <Passage 4> contain views on social interaction methods. Classify the passages into two different positions and summarize each position.
reference_answer:
<Passages 1> and <Passage 3> emphasize cooperative interaction methods, while <Passage 2> and <Passage 4> emphasize competitive interaction methods.
According to the position emphasizing cooperative interaction, cooperation based on reciprocity can be maintained and flourish as a successful interaction method, and when based on mutual trust and mutual regulation, cooperation can become an effective social problem-solving method. Here, <Passage 1> views that cooperation can emerge, flourish even in environments with all sorts of diverse strategies mixed together, and protect itself once established, regardless of the influence of individuals or social environments. It can even elicit cooperation from selfish individuals. <Passage 3> argues that the 'tragedy of the commons' situation can be resolved through cooperative methods rather than competitive methods or forced top-down methods. It explains that because humans always respond with cooperation when the other party's willingness to cooperate is confirmed, the problem can be sufficiently solved by providing appropriate incentives for community members to cooperate and autonomously equipping appropriate institutions for mutual monitoring and mutual sanctions. Ultimately, <Passage 1> emphasizes that maintaining and growing cooperation is not difficult, while <Passage 3> argues that the cooperative approach is a superior method for solving social problems.
The position emphasizing competitive interaction argues that while efforts to reduce the dysfunctions of the competitive system are necessary, competition is the only and most efficient method that can coordinate human behavior without external coercion. <Passage 2> emphasizes competition as a better guide to individual efforts than any other method. It views competition as not only the most efficient but also the only and superior method that can draw out and coordinate individual behavior without coercive and arbitrary interference from authority. <Passage 4> observes that although there are cases of forming cooperative relationships to avoid losing in competition, competition fundamentally induces companies to innovate. It emphasizes that while efforts are needed to weaken the side effects of competition, this should not damage the functions of the market economy that increase efficiency and progress through fair competition. Ultimately, while <Passage 2> merely emphasizes that competition is a superior method for coordinating individuals' individual efforts, <Passage 4> goes beyond to argue that competition should be the foundation of society while also advocating for temporary or partial introduction of cooperation to reduce the limitations or side effects of competition.
comment:
This problem asks you to classify four passages containing arguments about social interaction into two positions - cooperation-centered and competition-centered - and to summarize the key arguments of each position. The four passages can be classified as either cooperation-centered or competition-centered. The problem evaluates your ability to accurately understand, classify, and logically summarize the main points according to what the problem requires. The classification and main points of the passages are as follows:

(i) Cooperation-centered: Passages 1, 3
Passage 1) Cooperation is a form of interaction that can flourish regardless of individual or social environmental characteristics, based on reciprocity, and the requirements for cooperation to grow and be maintained are not difficult to meet.

Passage 3) Members of society can create a cooperative system that harmonizes self-interest and common interest through mutual regulation based on mutual trust.

Integrated Summary: Cooperation based on reciprocity can be maintained and flourish as a successful form of interaction, and when based on mutual trust and mutual regulation, cooperation can be an effective way to solve social problems.

(ii) Competition-centered: Passages 2, 4
Passage 2) While a certain legal framework is needed for competition to work beneficially, competition is the most efficient and only method that can draw out and coordinate individual efforts without interference from power.

Passage 4) While complements are needed to reduce the side effects of excessive competition, the competition mechanism fundamentally induces companies to focus more on innovation, so progress through fair competition should not be damaged.

Integrated Summary: While efforts to reduce the dysfunctions of the competitive system are necessary, competition is the only method that can draw out and coordinate individual efforts without external coercion, making it the most efficient approach that also keeps firms focused on innovation.

The key to writing a good answer is to accurately capture the central claims and grounds of each passage centered on the key themes of 'cooperation' and 'competition,' classifying them into the positions that 'cooperation is an effective form of social interaction' and 'competition is a superior form of social interaction,' and writing a summary by organically connecting the passages within each position.
With basic reading comprehension skills, classification should not be difficult, so it's important not just to classify the passages but to clearly and appropriately organize the content of each position. Therefore, based on an accurate understanding of each passage's position and central argument, summarizing and organizing passages classified in the same position into a unified text would receive a good evaluation.
For this reason, even if individual summaries of each passage are not included, there is no reason for deduction if the content of the two different positions is well organized to encompass the claims of the relevant passages. However, even if the individual passages are well summarized, points should be deducted if they are not integrated to organize the content of the two different positions. On the other hand, if the process of organizing arguments considers the differences in perspectives among passages classified in the same position, it would be considered an excellent answer.

* Inappropriate classification examples
1) Interaction through institutions (2, 3, 4) and interaction without institutions (1)
: Passage 1 does not explicitly mention interaction without institutions

2) State's forced intervention (4) and autonomous methods between individuals (1, 2, 3)
: Passage 1 does not explicitly mention this either. Passage 4 merely mentioned national intervention as one solution example but emphasized discussion for forming social consensus more.
checklist: Did the response clearly classify the passages into 'cooperative interaction' (<Passage 1>, <Passage 3>) and 'competitive interaction' (<Passage 2>, <Passage 4>) positions?
Did the response reflect the core content of <Passage 1> that reciprocity forms the basis of cooperation?
Did the response include the core content of <Passage 3> that mutual trust and mutual regulation are effective in solving social problems?
Did the response capture the core claim of <Passage 2> that competition is the most efficient method of coordinating individual efforts?
Did the response reflect the core content of <Passage 4> that efforts to reduce the dysfunctions of competition are necessary, but competition is important for innovation?

Did the response distinguish between <Passage 1>'s emphasis on cooperation being able to be maintained and flourish, and <Passage 3>'s argument that cooperation is a superior method for solving social problems?
Did the response distinguish between <Passage 2>'s emphasis on the efficiency of competition and <Passage 4>'s argument for introducing some cooperation to reduce the side effects of competition?
Did the response present the summary of each position (cooperation-centered, competition-centered) not merely as a list but by logically connecting them into an integrated presentation?

Did the response avoid inappropriate classifications (e.g., interaction through institutions vs. interaction without institutions, state intervention vs. autonomous methods between individuals, etc.) when classifying the passages?
Did the response clearly and evenly summarize the two positions with a focus on the core topic of social interaction methods?

passages:
<Passage1> Emotion is a world related to human instincts. Despite the fact that everyone experiences emotions and they are as important as reason, philosophy has ignored the world of emotions and only emphasized their suppression. Humans cannot live without emotions and regulate themselves through emotions. The emotions we feel are a criterion for knowing whether the body is functioning normally, and furthermore, they become an important criterion for judging the rightness or wrongness of facts. If something is right, we find peace of mind, and if something is wrong, we feel turmoil. It's as if emotions serve as a judge determining the rightness and wrongness of reason.
Philosophers have long asserted that reason is human while emotion is animal. They proclaimed that humans, as the lords of all creation, should escape from animal impulses and act according to reason. Despite Darwin's evolutionary theory revealing that humans are merely a continuation of animals, we comfort ourselves by believing that humans have distinctly human characteristics that are not animal-like. This stems from humanity's childish arrogance, but it was ignored by philosophers, and this trend was maintained for a long time. Emotion is an important mechanism for a living being's survival. If one feels at ease, it is favorable for survival, and if there is turmoil, something is being demanded. When emotion moves, it indicates something to oneself.
Humans are born with desires no different from animals. When desire is activated, it creates tension in the mind. The signal of this tension is emotion. When that desire is satisfied, the emotion is calmed. If it is not satisfied, the mind feels anxious and impatient until it is fulfilled. There are various types of emotions. They are that sensitive and delicate. The object of desire exists not only externally but also within one's mind. When we discover a fact that contradicts our beliefs, we feel tension because of it. And we must find an acceptable resolution in that situation to achieve emotional peace. Emotions are broadly divided into good and bad states. A good mood is a sign that things are going well, and a bad mood is a sign that things are not going well. Of course, the expression of emotions is diverse and the shades are subtle. As civilization developed, the diversity of emotions became more complex and sophisticated. This can be said to be a human characteristic, but since emotional demands are related to survival, their basic essence is no different from animals and is closely related to the fulfillment of desires. If animal desires are not satisfied, even humanity is lost. Humans are more powerless to animal desires than other animals. So humans ultimately cannot escape animal constraints. Without animal attributes, humans could not exist.
For humans, reason is important, but so is emotion. In some cases, emotion may be more honest and accurate than reason. When a person is overwhelmed with emotion, they may lose reason and commit unpredictable acts. Emotions must be cherished too. Reason can only function when emotions are stable. Modern science has also begun a serious examination of emotions. Emotion is fundamentally one of the psychological functions based on sensory organs. It is distinguished from reason, which is an ability independent of sensory organs, and operates as motivators such as recognition, nostalgia, attachment, affection, sympathy, aesthetic sense, or imagination in daily life. Without the common feelings of emotion, excitement, and empathy, one cannot expect enthusiasm or self-innovation from humans. The philosopher Hume also thought that emotions have an independent ethics that cannot be controlled by reason, and argued that emotion is the foundation of ethics. Kant thought that judgments not motivated by practical reason should all be doubted, but Hume thought that reason is emotion without passion. Thus, he argued that humans are essentially animals driven by emotions, and reason only operates when those emotions lose their heat.

<Passage2> Animals respond through behaviors such as licking each other amicably when other members return favors and making growling sounds to threaten them when they don't, but humans respond through ethical judgments of approval or condemnation. One might object that such judgments are merely refined versions of friendly licking and growling noises. But one difference is clear. In the case of growling or licking, there's no need to justify the action, but in the case of ethical judgment, one must be able to defend one's judgment. If people can argue and ask, "Why did you do that?" they have evolved from simple growling or licking to ethical judgment.
A dog may growl at one person but wag its tail at another, and it doesn't need to justify this difference. But humans find it difficult to pass over without giving reasons when they make different ethical judgments about the same situation. For instance, if someone says they can take fruits gathered by members of other tribes but no one should take their own, they will inevitably be questioned about why the two cases should be different. And they must provide appropriate reasons for this. Demanding reasons in this way is a demand for justification that the entire group can accept. Therefore, the reasons must be fair and acceptable to everyone. In other words, one must choose a viewpoint that is common with others, escaping from private and specific situations.
The demand for impartiality, that is, the attitude of equally considering the interests of all people who will be affected by one's actions, means that one cannot secure justification through a shameless appeal to self-interest. For example, one cannot argue that it is inevitable for me to take fruit from others because it is disadvantageous if others take fruit from me but advantageous if I take fruit from others. If one wants to gain the consent of the entire group, one's position must be as fair as possible. For example, one might say that as a brave warrior, they have the right to take more fruit. Such justification is fair in the sense that it implies that any warrior as brave as oneself should have as much fruit. Conversely, such justification implies that those who are not as good at fighting should take less fruit.
Ethics is established by extending the element of impartiality inherent in the idea of justifying our actions in relation to society as a whole as a principle. This principle ultimately requires consideration not only of my interests but also equal consideration of the interests of all people who will be affected by a choice. This principle requires that when I make an ethical judgment, I decide only from a fair perspective. In other words, it asks what choice I will make after imagining the lives of all who will be affected by my decision.

<Passage3> Humans have the power to think continuously, while other animals act according to instinct. Animals other than humans cannot logically discern or judge whether something is right, not right, true, or not true. Animals can also find food through their senses. However, animals other than humans cannot logically infer why food is there. Humans can infer why food is there by considering various conditions necessary for food, such as water being present for trees to grow, or the soil being fertile, or the sunshine being good. Furthermore, humans can create such conditions artificially to continuously produce food. In human society, reason is the driving force that has enabled characteristically human activities different from other animals, such as philosophy, science, linguistics, mathematics, and art. Decisively, reason is the force that allows one to subjectively change self-awareness or beliefs, existing institutions, or traditions. Human reason forms the true foundation of freedom and self-determination. Humans as rational beings not only autonomously establish moral laws but also have the power of will to lead their self-set principles of action to conform to universal moral laws.
The traditional view of rational consumption explains that it is right for consumers to make objectively the best decision by comparing various alternatives with valid reasons and purposes, and that rational consumption focusing on practicality is the core of rational consumption. This can be called 'instrumentalism' in that it considers only the choice of the best means to realize a purpose as the rationality of homo economicus. Plato argued that no one acts contrary to what they consider the best principle, so only ignorance is the only element explaining irrational behavior. Some scholars have named the principle of instrumentalist rationality the 'Platonic Principle' by citing this claim. From this instrumentalist position, human desires are considered extrinsic, and instrumental rationality, which focuses on the consistency between the actor's desires, beliefs, and actions within a given system of desires, is important. We can think about what effects alternatives will have on ourselves and judge consistently when selecting various alternatives. Moreover, we have a value system that can evaluate these effects and determine rankings within the range of feasible sets based on that evaluation.
In a society where the principle of scarcity is inevitable, the judgment of justice is difficult to separate from the question of which values to prioritize. This is because in order to examine how rational an individual's desire itself is, a value system judging purposive rationality regarding the content of the desire or its formation process must be established first. At the center of this problem is reason. Reason distinguishes between right and wrong, good and evil, righteous deeds and deceitful deeds, enabling humans to make autonomous and moral judgments. The human capacity for rational thinking is connected to free action and thought. A human as a rational being is an autonomous being who enjoys true freedom through actions according to their own judgment, and also has the ability to bear responsibility for those actions. Therefore, rational desires must be judged internally in the decision-maker's decision-making process and are generated from understanding based on appropriate experiences or evidence. Therefore, rational consumption is ultimately made according to consistent and rational judgments based on individual preferences.

<Passage4> Are our moral views based on reason? Do ethical values of right and wrong objectively exist? And are they unchanging regardless of time and place? In <History> written by Herodotus, there is the following story. The Callatians habitually ate the corpses of their ancestors and believed it was the right thing to do. In contrast, the Greeks cremated corpses and thought it was the correct way to handle bodies. So should we eat corpses or burn them? When different cultures have different moral norms like this, can one of them necessarily be right? The idea that different cultures have their own moral norms and that no single one of them can be objectively right has seriously undermined the objectivity and immutability of morality.
I want to go a step further and argue that moral views are based on our emotions and nothing more. 'Objective' right and wrong do not exist. When I say that some person is good and some person is evil, I am not making an objective judgment but merely talking about my feelings about them. It is a fact that Hitler and his henchmen killed millions of innocent people. But when I say that what they did was bad, I am by no means making an objective assessment of the facts. An objective assessment involves applying objective value standards and implies that everyone should evaluate it that way. But the truth is not so. When we say that what they did was bad, we are saying that we have negative feelings about their actions. The claim that homosexuals are bad is likewise nothing more than a claim that one has negative feelings about homosexuality. This applies equally to all moral judgments.
In the end, morality is not a discussion of which things or actions are good and which things or actions are evil. Morality does not tell us how to live or which views we must follow. Whatever moral judgment we make, we are actually only expressing personal feelings and nothing more. We can have moral opinions on issues and recognize or oppose the rights of homosexuals. But whatever position we take, that choice does not represent truth but is simply expressing one's personal feelings.

Humanities/Social Science.question: The provided <Material1> and <Material2> show indicators related to A country's livestock market changes and B country's food consumption by city, respectively. <Passage1> ~ <Passage4> contain views on what human actions are based on, and these passages can be classified into two opposing positions. Explain which position each of <Material1> and <Material2> supports.
Humanities/Social Science.materials:
<Material1> Trends in A country's livestock market changes

Year | Domestic pork production (M/T) | Pork imports (M/T) | Domestic swine disease outbreaks | Major exporting countries' swine disease outbreaks | Domestic pork consumption (M/T)
-----|------------------------|-------------------|----------------------|--------------------------|----------------------
2017 | 954,900 | 428,000 | 0 | 0 | 943,100
2018 | 955,200 | 310,000 | 0 | 2 | 891,700
2019 | 955,100 | 280,000 | 0 | 5 | 789,600
2020 | 954,800 | 430,000 | 0 | 0 | 942,800

Note 1) All other conditions in country A are assumed to be the same throughout the period.
Note 2) Swine diseases have been scientifically proven over the past 100 years not to infect humans.
Note 3) M/T means metric ton (1,000kg) in the metric system.
<Material2> Food consumption indicators by city in country B

The information in <Material2> is a bar graph comparing 3 different groups (A, B, C). The graph shows 4 different indicators, labeled as "Food labeling utilization", "Food safety information utilization", "Nutritional balance status", and "Food consumption satisfaction". For each indicator, values for the three groups are shown:
- Group "A" is represented by black bars (Food labeling utilization 4.7, Food safety information utilization 4.1, Nutritional balance status 4.6, Food consumption satisfaction 4.5).
- Group "B" is represented by gray bars (Food labeling utilization 2.3, Food safety information utilization 1.9, Nutritional balance status 3.1, Food consumption satisfaction 2.4).
- Group "C" is represented by white bars (Food labeling utilization 3.1, Food safety information utilization 2.5, Nutritional balance status 3.6, Food consumption satisfaction 2.9).

The y-axis of the graph is scaled from 0 to 5, with markings at 0.5 unit intervals. The main scale points are 0, 0.5, 1, 1.5, 2, 2.5, 3, 3.5, 4, 4.5, 5. Each bar has the exact value labeled on top.
<Material Explanation>
1. Food labeling utilization refers to the level of utilizing nutritional information, expiration dates, etc., that are mandatory on food labels when purchasing food.
2. Food safety information utilization refers to the level of utilizing the food safety information portal site operated by the government when purchasing food.
3. Nutritional balance status refers to the degree of excellence in the balanced level of nutrients included in the diet normally consumed.
4. Food consumption satisfaction refers to the degree to which one judges that they have made a satisfactory choice after purchasing food.
5. All items were measured on a 5-point scale (1=very low, 5=very high).
6. All other conditions in the three cities (A, B, C) are assumed to be the same.
comment:
This problem requires you to interpret two materials in relation to two positions and explain how each material can be used to support these positions. To do this, you need to interpret the two materials to relate the phenomena shown in the two countries to human rational and emotional actions, and connect each material to one of the positions.

To solve the problem, you first need to interpret <Material1> and <Material2> separately and infer how the phenomena shown in each material relate to the two opposing positions. <Material1> shows the changes in A country's livestock market from 2017 to 2020, specifically showing pork production, imports, domestic and foreign swine disease outbreaks, and domestic pork consumption. Among these, domestic pork consumption represents consumer choice outcomes, and you need to determine what factors influenced the changes in consumption within the given material. The data shows that as swine disease outbreaks in major exporting countries increased (2 cases in 2018, 5 cases in 2019), imports decreased during that period. On the other hand, there were no swine disease outbreaks domestically, and domestic pork production actually slightly increased. However, looking at changes in domestic pork consumption, we can see that consumption of domestic pork decreased during 2018 and 2019 when swine diseases occurred in major exporting countries, and then recovered to 2017 levels in 2020. Therefore, we can infer that concerns about swine diseases in major exporting countries also affected domestic pork consumption.

<Material2> presents food consumption-related indicators for cities 'A, B, C' in country B. First, you need to interpret that food labeling utilization and food safety information utilization indicate patterns of food selection behavior. Food labeling utilization and food safety information utilization can be interpreted as the more effort put into using objective information when purchasing food, the higher the value, which means selecting food based on cognitively processing information and making rational judgments. Nutritional balance status and food consumption satisfaction should be interpreted as results of food choices. Nutritional balance status can be interpreted as an objective evaluation result, and food consumption satisfaction as a subjective evaluation result. Looking at the specific food consumption patterns of the three cities, both food labeling utilization and food safety information utilization are highest in city 'A' and lowest in city 'B', and nutritional balance status and food consumption satisfaction, which show the results of food consumption behavior, are also highest in city 'A' and lowest in city 'B'. Based on this data, you can infer that food consumption behaviors related to food labeling and food safety information utilization are rational behaviors based on reason, and that such behaviors led to positive results in both nutritional balance status and food consumption satisfaction. That is, you can infer that rational information processing resulted in favorable outcomes.

In summary, <Material1> suggests that human behavior may be influenced by emotions rather than rational judgments. Considering that swine diseases do not infect humans, as scientifically proven over the past 100 years, and that no swine diseases occurred domestically, a rational judgment would consider domestic pork to be free from risk from swine diseases. However, the changes in domestic pork consumption shown in the data suggest that human behavior can be influenced by emotions. Therefore, <Material1> can be interpreted as supporting the argument that the world of emotions cannot be ignored and that humans are essentially animals driven by emotions. <Material2> supports the importance of rational judgment in human behavior by showing that better nutritional balance status and higher satisfaction were achieved as a result of using objective information for rational food purchases. Choosing food with extensive use of information related to nutrition and safety means considering objective principles of action for rational decision-making. Looking at the food consumption patterns of the three cities in detail, the level of utilization of food labeling and food safety information, i.e., rational decisions based on objective information, was higher in city 'A' than in other cities, and the city also had better nutritional balance status and satisfaction. This can be interpreted as supporting the claim that humans make rational comparisons of various alternatives with reasonable reasons and purposes and make the best decisions objectively, and that such reason-based behavior choices are desirable.

To summarize, the two materials provided show the action of reason and emotion as the basis for human behavior and their results, thus showing opposing positions on human behavior. A good answer's point is to present a consistent logic to defend the two positions distinguished in the problem using the two materials provided. When writing your answer, the expected directions of discussion are as follows.

First, relating the two materials to the two positions, you can discuss that <Material1> supports the position that 'human behavior is based on emotion', while <Material2> supports the position that 'human behavior is based on rational judgment'. In the case of <Material1>, it shows a cause that induces negative emotions about pork and the resulting decreased domestic pork consumption, indicating human behavior according to emotions, but it does not provide a basis for judging whether such human behavior is right or wrong. However, according to <Passage1> and <Passage4>, emotions can be an important criterion for judging the rightness or wrongness of facts, and since there is no objective right or wrong and human judgment only follows personal emotions, it can be argued that the risk felt by consumers in country A is a right judgment in itself. On the other hand, <Material2> presents the positive results of better nutritional balance status and satisfaction when utilizing information corresponding to objective facts, thus presenting the phenomenon of rational judgment being at the basis of behavior and its positive results. <Passage2> emphasizes that a basis for judgment is needed for 'why this is happening' and justification of the action is necessary. <Passage3> argues that humans should be able to make the best decisions objectively with reasonable reasons and purposes based on their continuous thinking power, and that such rational behavior is considered right. It emphasizes that in the process of establishing a value system for judging rationality, the action of reason is required, and even if it is a subjective value system such as individual preferences, it is important to make consistent and rational judgments according to judgment criteria generated by appropriate experiences or evidence. Therefore, in interpreting <Material2>, it is important to effectively connect that using objective information, which is the basis for rational judgment, such as food labeling information or safety information, not only led to better results in objective nutritional balance status but also led to positive results in food consumption satisfaction, which is a subjective judgment of the individual. That is, it is important to effectively explain that actions according to reason, which can objectively judge the rightness and wrongness of actions as argued in <Passage2> and <Passage3>, can be consistently evaluated according to grounds that can be validly applied to anyone, and the results were also better when actions were based on them.

If the materials are not properly connected to the positions in the passages, one might argue that both <Material1> and <Material2> advocate for the superiority of rational judgment. <Material1> shows the result of a decline in domestic pork consumption unrelated to foreign swine diseases due to being swayed by emotions, and there is no explicit basis for judging the rightness or wrongness of this. On the other hand, <Material2> shows that better nutritional balance status and food consumption satisfaction were achieved by utilizing information that is the basis for rational judgment. Since <Passage1> and <Passage4> emphasize that objective rightness and wrongness in human actions do not exist and what is right is based on human emotions, it is appropriate to interpret <Material1> as showing that emotions are important in human behavior choices and are right in themselves. Since both emotions and reason appear in the passages as principles for judging the rightness and wrongness of behavior, it would be difficult to receive a good evaluation if both <Material1> and <Material2> are used to advocate for the superiority of rational behavior.

If, in interpreting <Material2>, you focus only on which of reason and emotion the three cities' actions represent, and present a simple logic that <Material2> supports both positions, it would also be difficult to receive a good evaluation. <Material2> presents not only reason and emotion as the basis for action but also nutritional balance status, which can judge the objective result of the action, and food consumption satisfaction, which can judge the subjective result. Therefore, a richer answer would infer and logically explain the results of actions following reason and actions following emotions through this information. Also, a key element of evaluation will be whether you have effectively connected the explanations of the materials with the logic of advocacy for each position, going beyond simply repeating phrases from the passages.

Did the response clearly state that in <Material1>, the scientific fact that swine disease has been harmless to humans for over 100 years and the domestic outbreak count (0 cases) shows that the decrease in domestic pork consumption was based on emotion rather than rational judgment?

Did the response explicitly identify the food labeling utilization (A: 4.7, B: 2.3, C: 3.1) and food safety information utilization (A: 4.1, B: 1.9, C: 2.5) in <Material2> as behaviors based on rational judgment?

Did the response clearly explain that in <Material2>, the city with high rational information utilization ('A') achieved positive results in both nutritional balance status (4.6) and food consumption satisfaction (4.5), including specific numerical values?

Did the response clearly argue, based on <Material1>, that the correlation between swine disease outbreaks in major exporting countries and changes in domestic pork consumption shows that emotional anxiety influenced behavior despite no objective risk?

Did the response clearly demonstrate, through comparing city indicators in <Material2>, that rational judgment (objective information utilization) led to superior results in both objective evaluation (nutritional balance) and subjective evaluation (consumption satisfaction), including specific figures?
Did the response clearly distinguish the two opposing positions (emotion vs. reason) from the passages and accurately connect them with the numerical information in <Material1> and <Material2>?

Did the response clearly explain that the justification for rational judgment requires objective grounds that everyone can accept, using content from <Passage2> or <Passage3>?
