passages: <Passage1> The belief that income redistribution can reduce the gap between classes is merely an illusion. Unless wealth is widely distributed among members of society to eliminate inequality, it is impossible to fundamentally prevent political inequality caused by the concentration of wealth and capital, and political power tends to be exercised for the benefit of privileged classes. In particular, there is a high probability that wealthy classes will politically exclude poor classes and drive political decisions in their favor. This distortion also transfers to the education sector, giving children of wealthy and powerful people privileges and benefits that children of low-income families cannot enjoy, and the inheritance of wealth becomes entrenched. In the academic competition prevalent in many countries around the world, academic credentials have become a basis for differentiation rather than a criterion for human capital or productive capacity. For example, academic credentials have become a mechanism to control the conditions for new entrants and limit supply to protect and strengthen the market value of the relevant profession in the field. Therefore, if one's expertise is recognized through academic competition, they secure a protection mechanism known as social closure. High academic credentials and prestigious school backgrounds are used as important procedures for gaining recognition of expertise rather than for acquiring knowledge and skills. As specialization is used as a social exclusion mechanism, the market economy principle that "prices should be formed in the market according to the principles of demand and free competition" collapses. According to Parkin (1979), exclusion is a strategy by which privileged groups block unprivileged groups from accessing resources or rewards in order to maintain or expand their current advantages, requiring qualifications based on credentialism or professionalism as essential conditions. Whenever privileged groups face the risk of losing opportunities they have enjoyed due to challenges from unprivileged groups, they strengthen the conditions for unprivileged groups to access the opportunities they enjoy, thereby breaking their will or rendering them powerless. In the end, the strategy of redistributing basic goods allocated through unfair market competition after the fact, rather than creating fair conditions before basic goods are distributed through market competition, does not guarantee the fairness of market competition. As a result, it erodes the foundation of political democracy by deepening political inequality stemming from economic inequality. Therefore, efforts should be made to create conditions as fair as possible before competition in the market begins in earnest, so that the results of competition are fairly accepted by everyone. Otherwise, the monopoly of productive capital and the structural amplification of inequality will distort market competition and democratic political processes, creating a problem where wealthy asset owners arbitrarily dominate other classes. To establish and maintain a fair system of cooperation among free and equal citizens, it is necessary to provide all citizens with sufficient means of production to become fully cooperative members of society before competition in the market begins. These means include not only physical capital but also human capital, that is, understanding of knowledge and institutions, educated abilities, and trained skills. This is the way to treat all citizens, considered as free, equal, and dignified individuals, equally and fairly, and it is the best way to maintain society as a fair system of cooperation among equal citizens.

<Passage2> The institutions and behaviors of a society can be explained as functions performed by members of society in the process of meeting the demands of social survival. This is similar to how various elements constituting an organism perform different roles and behaviors to meet the survival needs of that organism. Since the environments in which members of society find themselves inevitably differ, and consequently they face different survival needs, the ways in which these needs are met also differ. Institutions or behaviors should be understood in terms of the functional necessities they must satisfy. Therefore, the extent to which social institutions or behaviors contribute to the adaptation and regulation of the entire social system should be considered most important. All societies are structured and operated so that members perform different tasks according to their abilities. Even if duties are unpleasant or coercive, selection, socialization, and training processes are necessary to ensure that such tasks are performed properly. Even in primitive societies, there was role differentiation such as hunting, gathering, or preparing food. The contributions made by members performing different roles are evident to all, and since all members participate in tribal ceremonies, the group develops a shared value system and personality. In this way, the group's sense of solidarity is maintained. Role differentiation and social solidarity are important requirements of social life. These two can be found in both primitive and modern societies. In primitive societies, these requirements were met through informal educational activities that took place within the family or community. However, in modern society, where roles change between generations, a more formal structure is needed to educate young people, differentiate roles, and achieve group solidarity. To achieve this purpose, a public education system with universality and compulsory characteristics was established. School education performs an important social function of fostering skills and attitudes suitable for changing economic and social systems, and increases the possibility of employment, income, prestige, and authority being distributed fairly to individuals. Schools are also mechanisms that prevent income, social status, and authority from being distributed according to ascriptive characteristics such as family, race, gender, or religion, rather than ability, by further strengthening ability-based and talent-based selection devices. Rewards for talent are a prerequisite for modernization. In an ideally organized, functional modern society, individuals with the same job performance ability and motivation in a specific field are rewarded equally. In traditional societies, individuals had little opportunity to rise above their ascriptive status, and only those with appropriate birthright could receive training to become leaders. In contrast, in modern industrial societies, schools take the primary position in selection instead of parental status. Moreover, schools provide the training necessary for individuals to play certain roles within the existing social order. Modern schools carry out these tasks in a much more efficient, fair, and humane way than in the era when compulsory education did not exist.

<Passage3> Justice must not merely be done but must be 'seen to be done.' That is, justice must be evidently and indisputably visible. This is not an issue that applies only to one country; we must also consider the necessary conditions for justice when discussing the overall pros and cons of globalization or successful globalization. There is some justification for the claim that economic globalization has excellent advantages as an overall goal and contributes positively to the entire world. However, it is difficult to convince people that globalization, which is focused on economic development logic, is a clear blessing to everyone, including the extremely poor. This objection does not in itself diminish the value of globalization as a goal, but it suggests the need to examine why it is difficult to convince everyone that globalization is a 'clear and indisputable' good goal. In fact, the most important issue to consider in globalization is whether the benefits of economic ties, technological progress, and political opportunities can be well utilized as a means to provide appropriate benefits to deprived classes and the vulnerable. That is, rather than criticizing the importance of economic development itself and global economic relations, it is important to distribute the benefits of globalization fairly. Those who enthusiastically support globalization in its current form argue that the world's poor are generally not becoming poorer but are gradually escaping poverty, and this serves as an important basis for their advocacy. The logic is that globalization is not unfair to the poor and these poor people are also benefiting, so what's the problem? Will the poor become poorer or more affluent? Even if the poor can become slightly more affluent, it is unreasonable to assume that the poor receive a fair distribution of economic interrelationships and enormous potential benefits through globalization. The focus of the appropriate question is not whether international inequality is slightly expanding or contracting. Rather, the important issue is whether it is possible to distribute political, economic, and social opportunities fairly, and if so, what kind of international and domestic agreements to choose. In globalized international relations, the market economy does not operate alone, and it cannot operate alone even within a specific country. In globalized relationships, the overall system including the market (how physical resources are distributed, how human resources are developed, universal principles of corporate relations, aspects of established social security agreements, etc.) can cause very different results individually according to various conditions. Moreover, these conditions themselves also greatly depend on political, economic, and social institutions operating domestically and internationally. In general, world capitalism is much more interested in expanding the field of market relations than in establishing democracy, expanding basic education, or promoting social opportunities for the socially vulnerable. As a result, it deepens inequality not only between countries but also in many countries where the conditions necessary to realize equality are weak. Therefore, globalization that amounts to merely market globalization is a very inappropriate approach in terms of world prosperity, and it is tantamount to giving a kind of indulgence to many wealthy countries that are passive in resolving inequality issues within their own countries. The unfairness that has established itself as a characteristic of the world is closely linked to various responsibilities that must be resolved in institutional agreements, and these responsibilities are issues that must be fulfilled for the sake of basic global justice. These issues include unfair and inefficient trade sanctions, political barriers that block the distribution of emergency medicines crucial for treating diseases such as AIDS, and the logic of capital that reduces the incentive to develop medicines like vaccines that need to be newly developed periodically. Even narrowing our perspective to within one country, it is easy to imagine that in a society where inequality is deepened, this series of responsibilities will be difficult to properly resolve.

<Passage4>
<Jin Sang> "The ruler of the State of Deng is truly a wise ruler, but it seems he has not yet heard the Way. A virtuous person cultivates fields with the people to eat, lights fires to cook rice, and also governs. Now, the State of Deng has granaries and warehouses for storing grain and goods taken from the people, which is like troubling the people to support oneself. How can this be called virtuous? A virtuous ruler should farm like the people, cook rice, and share hardships with them."
<Mencius> "Does Farmer Heo necessarily eat only after planting grain himself?"
<Jin Sang> "Yes, that's right."
<Mencius> "Well then, does Farmer Heo wear a hat on his head?"
<Jin Sang> "Yes, he wears a hat."
<Mencius> "What kind of hat does he wear?"
<Jin Sang> "He wears a hat woven from white silk."
<Mencius> "Did he weave it himself?"
<Jin Sang> "No, he exchanges it for the grain he cultivated."
<Mencius> "That's right... Does Farmer Heo cook rice with a cauldron or steamer and cultivate fields with iron tools?"
<Jin Sang> "Of course he does."
<Mencius> "Does he make them himself?"
<Jin Sang> "No, he exchanges grain for them."
<Mencius> "Exchanging grain for steamers or cauldron-like iron products is not harmful to potters or blacksmiths, so likewise, how could potters or blacksmiths exchanging the vessels or tools they make for grain be harmful to farmers? There are affairs of the great person who governs and affairs of the small person who engages in livelihood. Even if a person could combine the skills of various artisans in one body, if they must necessarily make and use everything themselves, this would be like drawing all the people of the world to be constantly busy on the roads without rest. This is because they would have to prepare everything they need by themselves. To prevent this hassle, it is said that 'some devote their minds to governing people, and some devote their labor to livelihood; those who labor with their minds govern others, and those who labor with their strength are governed.' Those who are governed by others pay taxes to support those who devote their minds, and those who govern others live off the people - this is the common principle of the world."
Humanities/Social Science.subject: Sociology (Social Inequality and Political Philosophy)
Humanities/Social Science.question:
<Passages 1> - <Passage 4> contain various views on inequality, and the passages can be classified into two opposing positions. Based on <Material 1> and <Material 2>, which compare Countries A and B, critique each of the two positions.¹⁾
Note1) Assume that all other conditions between the two countries are identical except for what is presented in the materials.
Humanities/Social Science.materials:
<Material1> Economic indicators of two countries (5-year average, 2015-2019)

| Economic Indicator | Country A | Country B |
|---|---|---|
| National Income (in US dollars) | 23,002 | 30,999 |
| Unemployment Rate | 4.80% | 2.73% |
| Number of Patent Developments | 16,367 | 119,012 |
| Number of Innovative Enterprise Startups per 1,000 Population | 1.70 | 4.50 |
| R&D Investment Ratio to GDP | 2.50% | 6.80% |
| Global Innovation Index Ranking | 15 | 5 |
| 5-Year National Income Annual Growth Rate Forecast (World Bank) | 2.0% | 3.6% |
<Material2> Social indicators of two countries (5-year average, 2015-2019)
<Material2-1> College Enrollment Rate by Income Quintile²⁾ (Unit: %)
This chart is a bar graph comparing data between Countries A and B across five intervals, from the 1st quintile to the 5th quintile. The y-axis scale of this chart is displayed from 0% to 90%, with markings at 10% intervals.

Country A (dotted/patterned bars) specific values:
- 1st quintile: approximately 58 units
- 2nd quintile: approximately 57 units
- 3rd quintile: approximately 60 units
- 4th quintile: approximately 58 units
- 5th quintile: approximately 59 units

Country B (solid dark blue bars) specific values:
- 1st quintile: approximately 25 units
- 2nd quintile: approximately 48 units
- 3rd quintile: approximately 61 units
- 4th quintile: approximately 69 units
- 5th quintile: approximately 81 units
Note2) Income quintiles 1-5 classify the national income into 5 intervals, with the 5th quintile representing the top 20%.

<Material2-2> Social Stability Indicators
| Social Stability Indicator | Country A | Country B |
|---|---|---|
| Income Concentration³⁾ | 35% | 67% |
| Percentage of Households Below Minimum Housing Standards | 16% | 38% |
| Number of Subsistence Crimes per 100,000 Population | 641 | 1,916 |
| National Policy Trust Index⁴⁾ | 81 | 42 |
Note3) The percentage of total national income held by the top 20% of the population.
Note4) A measure of citizens' trust in national policies on a scale of 1-100, with higher scores indicating higher trust.
comment:
In this problem, you need to critique two positions using the two materials provided. To do this, you must interpret the two materials to understand the phenomena exhibited in the two countries and interpret each material according to two contrasting perspectives on inequality.

To solve the problem, you first need to interpret <Material 1> and <Material 2> and infer how the phenomena in each material relate to the two opposing positions. <Material 1> presents the 5-year average of various economic indicators for two countries, A and B, from 2015 to 2019. You need to identify the differences in economic indicators between the two countries and determine which position these differences might critique. Under the assumption that all other conditions are identical, Country B shows higher national income and lower unemployment rates than Country A. Additionally, through patent development numbers, innovative enterprise startup numbers, and R&D investment ratio to GDP, you can also infer that Country B's growth potential is also superior to that of Country A. When interpreting these indicators comprehensively, you can see that compared to Country A, Country B is more active in developing new technologies and investment, resulting in active patent development and innovative enterprise startups, and consistent with this trend, Country B has a higher ranking in the global innovation index and a higher forecast for annual growth rate of national income over the next 5 years.

<Material 2> shows social indicators for the same period in both countries. From this material, you need to interpret that the level of multiple disparities (i.e., differences between classes not only in income but also in other indicators) is different in both countries, and there are also differences in social stability indicators. First, looking at <Material 2-1>'s college enrollment situation, Country A shows almost no difference in college enrollment rates according to income quintile, while in Country B, higher income corresponds to higher college enrollment rates. This confirms that educational disparities according to income are greater in Country B than in Country A. <Material 2-2> shows social stability indicators for both countries, among which income concentration and the percentage of households below minimum housing standards confirm the pattern of multiple disparities in Country B. Income concentration, which is the percentage of total national income held by the top 20% of the population, shows that the level of income inequality is more severe in Country B than in Country A. Additionally, Country B has a significantly higher percentage of households below minimum housing standards than Country A. Meanwhile, <Material 2-2> also shows the pattern of conflict within the countries through the number of subsistence crimes and the national policy trust index. The number of subsistence crimes per 100,000 population is higher in Country B than in Country A, and the national policy trust index is lower in Country B than in Country A. You can infer that Country B not only has more conflict and instability factors within society compared to Country A but also has lower trust in policies implemented by the nation, showing a divided society. Therefore, from <Material 2-1> and <Material 2-2>, you should be able to infer the pattern of multiple disparities in income, education, and housing existing in society, as well as the pattern of conflict and division within society.

Interpreting these materials comprehensively in relation to the two positions, the following can be inferred: <Material 1> shows clear differences between Countries A and B in terms of economic growth potential as indicated by patents, innovative enterprise startups, and research and development (R&D) investment, resulting in differences in the global innovation index and national income annual growth rate forecast. Country B, compared to Country A, has relatively high patent development, active startups, and R&D investment, achieving a high ranking in the global innovation index, and its national income growth forecast is also higher than that of Country A. On the other hand, from <Material 1>, we can infer that despite Country B's superiority over Country A in various indicators of economic development potential, <Material 2> shows that in Country B, a society with intensified multiple disparities in income, housing, and education, crime, distrust of national policy, and other social instability factors are more severe than in Country A.

<Material 1> and <Material 2> provide complex grounds to critique both perspectives on social inequality, so you need to understand the indicators of inequality and the results brought about by inequality shown in each material. The key to a good answer is to comprehensively interpret and utilize the three materials to present consistent logic in critiquing the two positions classified from <Passages 1> - <Passage 4>.
<Passage 2> emphasizes that differences in rewards according to ability and talent are necessary conditions for modernization and actually prevent unfair distribution based on ascriptive characteristics, and <Passage 4> argues that the roles performed by each in their distinguished positions according to ability promote the functions of society, allowing for a critique of the social phenomena observed in Country A. The basis for this critique can be found in <Material 1>, where Country A shows poorer performance in patent development, innovative enterprise startups, and research and development investment ratio compared to Country B, as well as a lower ranking in the global innovation index. Investment in research and development helps those with sufficient ability to demonstrate excellent research and development performance, and while Country B intensively invests social resources according to ability and talent, Country A is passive in such investment, resulting in stagnation of the country's economic growth. This can be confirmed by Country A's lower 5-year national income growth forecast compared to Country B. Based on this interpretation, you can critique the position that rejects meritocracy and emphasizes the dysfunctional aspects of inequality as presented in <Passage 1> and <Passage 3>.
Conversely, as argued in <Passage 1>, economic inequality brings about social conflict, and if not resolved, multiple disparities occur not only in income but also in indicators such as education and housing, which can be explained through <Material 2>. Although Country B creates excellent economic performance compared to Country A, it has intensified multiple disparities, and social stability indicators show that there are significant instability factors and low trust in national policies compared to Country A, indicating a divided society. Based on this interpretation, you can critique the position that advocates for meritocracy and emphasizes the functional aspects of inequality as presented in <Passage 2> and <Passage 4>.

Focusing only on economic indicators from <Material 1> that align with the perspective emphasizing the functional aspects of inequality to justify <Material 2>, or focusing only on inequality indicators from <Material 2> to advocate for the perspective emphasizing the dysfunctional aspects of inequality, will not receive a good evaluation. It is also important to go beyond simply repeating phrases from the passages and to effectively connect the three materials to the two positions in a logical presentation.
checklist: Does the response classify <Passages 1>-<Passage 4> as 'various views on inequality' and clearly distinguish them into two opposing positions?

Does the response accurately interpret <Material 1> to show that Country B is superior to Country A in economic indicators (national income, unemployment rate, patent development, innovative enterprise startups, R&D investment, global innovation index, growth rate forecast)?

Does the response specifically analyze <Material 2-1>'s college enrollment rates by income quintile to show that Country A has almost no educational disparity by income, while Country B shows higher enrollment rates as income increases?

Does the response clearly interpret <Material 2-2>'s social stability indicators to show that Country B has higher income concentration, higher percentage of households below minimum housing standards, higher subsistence crime rates, and lower policy trust than Country A?
Does the response accurately classify <Passage 2> and <Passage 4> as 'a position that advocates for meritocracy and emphasizes the functional aspects of inequality'?
Does the response accurately classify <Passage 1> and <Passage 3> as 'a position that rejects meritocracy and emphasizes the dysfunctional aspects of inequality'?

Does the response use <Material 1> to critique the position that rejects meritocracy (<Passage 1>, <Passage 3>) and logically connect Country A's relatively lower economic performance and growth potential?

Does the response use <Material 2> to critique the position that advocates for meritocracy (<Passage 2>, <Passage 4>) and logically connect Country B's multiple disparities and social instability factors?
Does the response analyze the relationship between economic performance and social inequality in the two countries comprehensively, rather than simply listing the given materials?
Does the response effectively connect the materials with the two positions from the passages without simply repeating their phrases, presenting a logical critique?

passages: [A] This is an event from the time of King Gogukcheon of Goguryeo recorded in 'Samguk Sagi' (History of the Three Kingdoms). King Gogukcheon went hunting and met a person crying sadly on the road. When the person said he was crying because it was difficult to support his mother due to famine, the king called Eulpaso, who was then the chief minister, and instructed him to devise countermeasures. This is how Jindaebeop was born, which can be considered Korea's first social security system. Jindaebeop was a relief system where the government distributed grain it held to poor and needy people during famine or spring poverty periods and had them repay it during the autumn harvest. Of course, there were temporary relief policies before Jindaebeop, but it is not an exaggeration to say that Jindaebeop was the first social security system established as a permanent institution. Eulpaso targeted widowers, widows, orphans, and sick or elderly people without supporters for relief, and devised a plan to lend grain to them from March to July according to the number of family members and have them repay it in October. The timing was decided this way because while people could survive on grain harvested in autumn during winter, there was no proper way to avoid starvation during spring and summer when the harvested food ran out and newly planted grain had not yet ripened.

[B]
What makes me think this morning is somewhat happy is
a cup of coffee and plenty of cigarettes in the pack,
having bus fare left even after curing my hangover.

What makes me think this morning is somewhat sad is
that even though there's no shortage in these few coins
I must worry about tomorrow morning too.

Though poverty is my profession
I can be proud in this shining sunlight
because even this sunlight has no bank account...

My past and future
My beloved sons and daughters,
Sometimes come to the lush grass by my grave
and say, here lies a life lived through suffering, nonetheless,
Let the wind blow strongly...

[C] Systems that help reduce expenditures in real life also help prevent or overcome poverty. For example, childcare fee reductions benefit not only the poor but have the effect of reducing living costs. If public rental housing is supplied cheaper than market prices, this means receiving support from the government for that difference, and furthermore has the effect of reducing living expenses. If dementia care or daytime protection is provided to elderly people with dementia, families can increase their time participating in income activities accordingly. If local children's centers or after-school programs protect children until later hours and furthermore reduce private education costs, income activity opportunities increase accordingly and living cost reduction effects occur. By providing such diverse services broadly, we can expect not only to alleviate poverty problems but also to actually improve the quality of life for citizens.

[D] In Japan, where 1 in 4 citizens is over 65 years old, to solve the problems of aging and elderly poverty after retirement, they sought to activate elderly economic activities to reduce the burden of support on the younger generation and solve labor shortage problems. Japan revised the 'Elderly Employment Stability Act' in 2013 to make retirement at 65 mandatory, and also introduced policies to provide subsidies to companies that re-employ retired elderly people. As a result of these efforts, in 2015, more than 70% of Japanese companies were calculated to be employing people over 65, and accordingly the number of elderly poor also decreased.

[E] In modern society, the elderly do not have only biological meaning, and there can be spaces where they can fully demonstrate their abilities and qualities. Also, there are plenty of cases where intellectual abilities do not decline despite increasing age. That is, cognitive abilities in aging are not necessarily proportional to mental age or calendar age. The elderly themselves should not only demand social support from their children and surroundings. They must be able to seek ways to become economic agents themselves. To do this, basic awareness of elderly poverty consciousness is needed, and a change in awareness to escape elderly poverty is necessary. To spend old age meaningfully and beautifully, preparation from youth is necessary. What should be prepared from youth to spend a healthy old age includes not only health but also an attitude of actively preparing for economic stability, work, and leisure. These three elements are indispensable for doing work in old age joyfully and meaningfully. That is, one cannot work without health, and without some degree of economic stability, it is also important to always learn new knowledge and further hone one's abilities to do work worth living for. Therefore, the elderly need an attitude of self-reliance, and they must step forward to select jobs according to their own abilities.

[F] As Western countries have experienced remarkable economic growth over the past two centuries and the benefits of free enterprise have spread widely, absolute poverty has significantly decreased in Western capitalist countries. However, poverty is a relative problem, and it is clear that even in Western countries, many people live in conditions generally considered poor. One means of solving this problem, and in many ways the most desirable means, is private charity. It is noteworthy that private charitable organizations and groups increased greatly in England and America during the mid-to-late 19th century, the heyday of laissez-faire. As government welfare activities have increased, private charitable activities have declined, with the latter being one of the major costs society has paid due to the former. Liberals readily accept the fact that a free society is actually closer to material equality than any other social system attempted so far. However, liberals see this as a desirable byproduct of a free society, not as a major justification for a free society. They welcome measures that promote both freedom and equality, such as measures to eliminate monopoly power and improve market functioning. Liberals think that private charitable acts focused on helping relatively unfortunate people are an example of freedom being used appropriately.
Humanities/Social Science.subject: Poverty and Social Welfare Policy
Humanities/Social Science.question: Classify passages [A] ~ [F] into groups with similar perspectives and summarize them.
reference_answer:
[A]~[F] show positions emphasizing individual-level solutions and social institutional-level solutions among methods to solve poverty. [B], [E], and [F] correspond to the individual-level perspective, and [A], [C], and [D] correspond to the social institutional-level perspective.
[B] resolves the poverty problem at an individual level by transcending the life hardships or unhappiness consciousness that poverty brings and confirming happiness in daily life. [E] states that to escape poverty, the elderly themselves need an attitude of self-reliance, such as maintaining health and cultivating new knowledge. [F] emphasizes from a liberal perspective that individual charitable acts are a major means to address society's poverty problems.
[A] introduces Jindaebeop, which lends grain to the poor in spring and summer and receives it back in autumn, which can be called a social security system of the Goguryeo era. [C] discusses the need for systems that reduce individual expenditures for overcoming poverty, such as childcare fee reductions, public rental housing supply, and dementia elderly care. [D] shows that the Japanese government is promoting policies to encourage elderly economic activities to solve elderly poverty problems in an aging era.
comment: The aim was to evaluate the ability to understand contrasting perspectives on methods to solve poverty and classify writings on various topics based on this understanding. The first corresponds to positions emphasizing individual-level solutions among poverty resolution methods, and the second corresponds to positions emphasizing social institutional-level solutions. Applicants are required to have the ability to classify given passages into two positions and summarize the core content of each passage according to the given length.
checklist: Does the response correctly identify and group the passages based on similar perspectives toward solving poverty (i.e., distinguishes between individual-level and institutional/societal-level perspectives)?
Does the response group [B], [E], and [F] together as representatives of the individual-level approach and provide justification based on the content of those passages?
Does the response group [A], [C], and [D] together as representatives of the social institutional or policy/system-level approach and provide justification based on the content of those passages?

Does the response explain the individual-level perspective for each of [B], [E], and [F], referencing specific rationales or attitudes (e.g., self-reliance, personal attitude, charity, individual happiness) rather than merely summarizing their content?

Does the response explain the institutional or policy-based perspective for each of [A], [C], and [D], referencing actions such as social security systems, government-led cost reductions, or state efforts to solve poverty, rather than merely summarizing their content?
Does the response avoid misclassifying any passage into the wrong group or failing to assign passages to any group?

Does the response go beyond mere listing by briefly summarizing or characterizing the perspective or solution presented within each passage or group (i.e., provides succinct rationales for the grouping)?

Does the response mention both the aspect of method (how poverty is addressed) and the perspective/agent (individual vs. institution/social system) as bases for classification, rather than classifying based on surface content features alone?

Law.subject: Community Property/Professional Responsibility
Law.question:
Wendy and Hal are married and live in California. 
A year ago, Wendy told Hal that she would not tolerate his drinking any longer. She insisted that he move out of the family home and not return until he completed an alcohol treatment program. He moved out but did not obtain treatment. 
Last month, Hal went on a drinking spree, started driving, and struck a pedestrian. When Wendy learned of the accident, she told Hal that she wanted a divorce.
Hal has consulted Lawyer about defending him in a civil action filed by the pedestrian. He is currently unemployed. His only asset is his interest in the family home, which he and Wendy purchased during their marriage. Lawyer offered to represent Hal if Hal were to give him a promissory note, secured by a lien on the family home, for his fees. Hal immediately accepted. 
1. Is Wendy's interest in the family home subject to damages recovered for injuries to the pedestrian? Discuss. Answer according to California law. 
2. Is Wendy's interest in the family home subject to payment of Hal's legal fees? Discuss. Answer according to California Law.
3. What, if any, ethical violations has Lawyer committed? Discuss. Answer according to California and ABA authorities.
reference_answer:
1. Is Wendy's Interest in the Family Home Subject to Damages Recovered for Injuries to the Pedestrian?
California is a Community Property State
California is a community property (CP) jurisdiction. Thus, any property acquired by either spouse during the course of the marriage by either spouse's labor is presumptively community property. Property acquired before or after the marriage by either spouse, or during the marriage by gift, inheritance, or devise, is presumptively separate property (SP). In determining the character of a particular asset, it is helpful to look at (1) the source of the asset or the source of the funds used to purchase the asset, (2) any actions by the spouses changing the character of the property, and (3) any relevant presumptions.
The House
Source
The facts tell us that Wendy (W) and Hal (H) purchased the family house during their marriage. However, we don't know what funds were used to purchase the house. If W's or H's earnings were used (or a combination thereof), and those earnings were earned during the course of the marriage, then the house would be CP because spousal earnings are CP to the extent they're earned during the marriage.
However, if one spouse partially used inheritance money or other SP acquired before the marriage, then that spouse would likely have a SP interest in the home to the extent SP was used to purchase it.
However, without more, the best assumption is that spousal earnings were used to purchase the house. The facts say H is currently unemployed, but he may have been employed in the past (and thus had earnings). Further, we can assume W earned money somehow, likely from a job. 
Actions
There is no evidence that the house was put in only one spouse's name, suggesting that the house was the separate property of that spouse. Pre-1975, if the house was in W's name, the married woman's special presumption would operate to render the house (or the share of the house in W's name) W's SP. 
Modernly, if title was taken in only one spouse's name, a court would not likely hold that to be conclusive evidence that the house was that spouse's SP absent some manifestation by the other spouse that the house was intended as a gift.
If H and W took title to the house as joint tenants with a right of survivorship, each would have a 1/2 SP undivided interest in the whole during life. On death, the form of title would control. On divorce, under CA's anti-Lucas statute, the house would be treated as CP, with a right to reimbursement for any SP used by either spouse to improve the home.
Finally, there's no evidence of a transmutation changing the character of the house, which, after 1985, would have to be in writing.
Thus, absent any of these actions, it appears the house is still CP.
Presumption
All property acquired during the course of marriage is presumptively CP. Here, nothing rebuts that presumption.
Community Responsibility for Debts of One Spouse
All debts incurred by either spouse prior to or during the course of marriage are community debts. Tort obligations are "incurred" when the tort occurs, not when judgment is handed down. Thus, any obligations arising out of H striking the pedestrian were "incurred" when he hit the pedestrian.
W will argue that the marital economic community was not in existence when H hit the pedestrian because she had kicked him out of the house. The marital economic community begins at marriage and terminates upon permanent physical separation when at least one spouse has no intent of continuing the marriage.
Here, W kicked H out of the house. However, she told him that he could return when he completed an alcohol abuse program. Thus, the marital economic community had not yet ended when H got in the accident because W was still open to the possibility of him returning. W will argue that H manifested an intent to never continue the marriage because he refused to go to treatment. In other words, W will argue that by rejecting the pre-condition to the continuation of the marriage--i.e. getting treatment--H effectively terminated the marital economic community. Indeed, W can point to the fact that 11 months after she kicked H out, he hadn't obtained treatment. Given this length of time, W can argue, it's clear that the community had ended.
However, the stronger argument is that the marital economic community continued until W told H that she wanted a divorce. If W viewed the marital community as over prior to the accident, she would have likely filed for divorce then. Instead, it appears the accident was the "last straw." Thus, the request for a divorce was the clearest signal by either party that the physical separation was permanent and there was no intent to continue the marriage. 
Thus, the marital economic community had not ended when H struck the pedestrian, any obligation incurred because of the accident is a community debt.
Order of Payment
When a tort is committed during an activity for the benefit of the community, the debt will be satisfied first by CP, then by the tortfeasor's SP. The non-tortfeasor spouse's SP is not subject to the debt.
When a tort is not committed during an activity for the benefit of the community, the debt will be satisfied first by the tortfeasor's SP, then by CP. Again, the other spouse's SP is safe. 
Here, H committed the tort against the pedestrian while driving drunk. This was not an activity for the benefit of the community--to the contrary, H was supposed to be seeking alcohol abuse treatment while he was living away from the family home. Thus, recovery would be taken out of H's SP before the CP.
However, on the facts, it doesn't seem as though H has any SP to satisfy the debt. Thus, any recovery will likely be against the H and W's CP.
Reimbursement to the Community
To the extent any CP--i.e. the house--is used to pay any obligation arising out of H's accident with the pedestrian, the community may be entitled to reimbursement from H. Where CP is used to pay an obligation arising out of spouse's tort that was committed not during an activity for the benefit of the community, the community is entitled to reimbursement for that payment if the tortfeasor's SP was available to pay (or if the order of payment was not followed). However, as mentioned, it doesn't appear H has any SP available to pay the debt and, thus, reimbursement may be unlikely.
Distribution of Debts on Divorce
At divorce, community assets are generally divided under the "equal division rule"--i.e. each spouse gets 1/2 of each community asset in kind. 
However, a judge has more discretion as to the allocation of debts at divorce. Typically, a judge will allocate a tort debt to the tortfeasor spouse if the tort was incurred not during an activity for the benefit of the community. However, a judge may take into account ability to pay to effect a more just allocation of debts.
Here, on divorce, the judge would likely allocate any judgment based on H striking the pedestrian to H. H will argue that he's unemployed and can't pay, but it's highly unlikely a judge would saddle W with an obligation to pay H's tort liability post-divorce.
Conclusion 
Thus, during the marriage, H and W's CP will be liable for damages recovered for injuries to the pedestrian. Even though H and W have filed for divorce, until community assets and debts are distributed, the community estate continues and the pedestrian can recover against it. However, as mentioned, on divorce, the debt will be allocated to H. Further, W may be entitled to reimbursement for CP used to pay the debt.
*Note: If the court decided that the marital community was terminated when H struck the pedestrian, then CP--i.e. the house--would not be liable for the debt because the debt would be H's SP.
2. Is Wendy's Interest in the Family Home Subject to Payment of H's Legal Fees
Equal Management
Each spouse generally has equal rights to manage community property. This includes the right to sell and encumber community property. However, with respect to real property, one spouse may not encumber community owned real property without the other spouse's consent. If one spouse, without consent, sells or encumbers community real estate, the non-consenting spouse has the power to void that transaction within 1 year. 
Lien on the House
Here, H has given Lawyer a lien on the family home without W's consent. Thus, W has the power within 1 year to void the encumbrance.
H will argue that because he gave the lien on the house after W told him she wanted a divorce, he was only granting a lien on his 1/2 SP interest in the family home. However, there's no evidence that W actually filed for divorce or that divorce proceedings were held during which a judge divided the community estate. While the marital economic community may no longer exist because there has been permanent physical separation, the community estate lives on until it has been distributed. 
Thus, a court would likely allow W to void the encumbrance on the community real property due to her lack of consent in making the encumbrance.
Timing of the Attorney's Fees
Furthermore, H sought legal advice after W told him she wanted a divorce. Because W asking for divorce terminated the marital economic community, CP--i.e. the family home--is not liable for the debts incurred by H after such separation.
Thus, any obligation owed to Lawyer based on legal services rendered to H cannot be satisfied out of CP because such an obligation would not be a community debt.
He would argue that payment of attorney's fees is an obligation arising out of the accident of the pedestrian, when the marital economic community still existed. However, the attorney's fees represent an entirely different event. Furthermore, contractual obligations arise when the contract was made. Here, any contract and/or agreement with Lawyer was made after the economic community ended. Therefore, W's interest in the family home is not subject to payment for the additional reason that CP is not liable for H's separate post-marriage debts.
Necessaries
Post-separation, a spouse can still be liable for obligations relating to necessaries that the other spouse incurred during the marriage. Necessaries generally refer to food, shelter, and medical expenses. Here, H's legal fees don't likely constitute necessaries and, as such, this theory cannot be invoked to hold W's interest in the family home subject to payment.
3. Lawyer's Ethical Violations
Obtaining Pecuniary Interest in Outcome of Case
Under the ABA, a lawyer cannot obtain a pecuniary interest in the subject matter of a case other than in the case of a contingency fee arrangement or an attorney's lien. However, in CA, attorneys' liens are impermissible. 
Here, Lawyer effectively acquired an attorney's lien on H's family home. Thus, Lawyer will argue that this was permissible because the only purpose here was to secure payment. In CA, this would constitute an ethical violation. Under the ABA, it's less clear.
While under the ABA, an attorney's lien is permissible, if Lawyer knew that H couldn't rightfully encumber the family home, then it's possible that Lawyer committed an ethical violation because accepting the attorney's lien would constitute a violation of a third party's (W's) rights in the course of representing H.
Entering into Business Transactions with Clients
An attorney can only enter a business transaction with a client if (1) the terms are fair and reasonable, (2) the terms are communicated to the client in an easily understandable manner, (3) the client is advised to get independent counsel to represent him in the transaction and is given a chance to do so, and (4) the client consents.
Here, by taking a lien on H's family home, Lawyer entered into a business transaction with H. However, it's not clear that Lawyer ever advised H to seek independent counsel or that he adequately informed him of the material terms of the lien. Although H immediately accepted, he did so without knowing what would trigger enforcement of the lien (1 missed payment? total failure to pay? late payment? H's insolvency?). Thus, by failing to adequately inform H and encouraging him to seek independent advice, Lawyer likely violated the ethics rules.
Fees
Under the ABA, a fee must be reasonable. In CA, fees can't be unconscionable. Further, in CA, a fee agreement must be in writing unless it's (1) less than $1k, (2) with a corporation, or (3) for a routine matter involving an existing client. 
Here, the lien agreement was essentially a fee agreement. However, the terms were not adequately disclosed to H. Further, there was no written fee agreement. Because a writing was likely required--there's no evidence H was an existing client or that Lawyer's services were valued at under $1k--this is a violation of CA rules.
Further, the lien was likely unreasonable and unconscionable. Because H was unemployed, it was extremely unlikely that he was going to be able to pay Lawyer's fees. If Lawyer knew that H was unemployed--which he likely did, considering he conditioned representing H on having a lien on the house--then Lawyer must have known that H wouldn't be able to pay. Thus, the fee agreement was unconscionable because it was akin to a mortgagee lending to a mortgagor knowing that the mortgagor was going to default and the foreclosure was inevitable. Lawyer must have known (a) that H wasn't going to be able to pay and (b) that the value of the lien on the home was worth more than the value of the services to be provided.
Thus, the fee arrangement likely constituted an ethical violation.
Violating Rights of Third Parties
Lawyers cannot violate the rights of third parties in the course of representing a client. To the extent the lien violates W's rights and Lawyer knew of this, he likely acted unethically. Furthermore, if Lawyer knew that H could not rightfully encumber the family house, then Lawyer arguably breached his duty of competent and candid representation by not informing H that he couldn't offer a lien on his house without W's consent.

1. Is Wendy's interest in the family home subject to damages recovered for injuries to the pedestrian hit by Hal under California law?
The parties were married and live in California. Thus, their property rights as a couple, specifically with regard to the property acquired during the marriage, are governed by California community property law. Whether the house was community or separate property can be determined by the source of the asset, whether any presumptions apply, and the actions of the parties during the marriage.
Community Presumption
There is a community presumption regarding property acquired during the marriage that it is community property. This would apply to the family home given, as the facts state, it was acquired during the marriage. The presumption can be rebutted by a showing that the house was not actually acquired during the marriage, it was acquired during the marriage but with separate property funds, the house was a gift/devise/inheritance, or the house was the rent/issue/profit derived from separate property.
Their house was purchased during the marriage so it was not a gift or devise. Although it is possible that the house was purchased with separate property funds, there are no facts to indicate this was the case. Because it was purchased during the marriage, and there are no facts to rebut the presumption, the house is considered community property.
Judgments Against Spouses
A tort judgment against a spouse will subject both the community property and the separate property of the tortfeasor to the judgment. But once the community property is divided, debt cannot be recovered from the spouse who received her half of the community property from what she received under the divorce decree unless she was the spouse that incurred the debt or the debt was assigned to her. Thus, for a judgment against Hal for drinking and driving, the community will be liable for this debt, and it can be satisfied from the community property.
For the Benefit of the Community
Although the community property is liable for the judgment by the pedestrian, the judgment must be satisfied first from the separate property of the tortfeasor spouse if the tort was not committed by conduct that was being performed for the benefit of the community. For example, if Hal was on his way to drop the kids off at school or to pay the mortgage on the house, this would be for the benefit of the community. In that case, the judgment would be satisfied first from community property, and if there was any deficiency, then from the separate property of the tortfeasor.
Here, Hal had been kicked out [of] the house for his drinking problem at the time of the accident. Wendy had clearly communicated her disapproval for Hal's drinking. The drinking, including drinking and driving, would actually harm, not benefit, the community. Although we do not know where Hal was headed, he had already been kicked out of the house and was, generally, involved in a drinking binge at the time. Therefore, his actions were not to the benefit of the community and can be satisfied first from his separate property assets.
But the facts state that his only asset, at the present time, is his interest in the family home. Because it appears he has no separate property from which to satisfy the judgment, the judgment will be satisfied from the community property home.
End of the Economic Community
The accident in which the pedestrian was hit occurred after Hal had been kicked out of the house but before Wendy told Hal she wanted a divorce. As stated above, the source of property or debt, whether it was incurred before, during or after the marriage, can indicate whether it is community or separate debt. The pedestrian's claim is a form of debt because, once rendered, the plaintiff can reduce it to a judgment and attach liens to the tortfeasor's property. Thus, the question arises whether the economic community ended when Wendy kicked Hal out of the house, because if so, the injury and judgment would have occurred after the economic community ended and would be the separate debt of Hal. In this case, the judgment could not be satisfied from community property, including the house.
In California, end of the economic community occurs when there is physical separation and an intent not to carry on the marital relationship anymore. If the parties maintain the facade or marriage, although physically separated, the economic community will not be considered to be at an end. The economic community will certainly result, if the above elements are not satisfied, when the divorce decree is entered.
Here, Wendy kicked Hal out of the house one year ago. She did not say anything about ending the marriage or never wanting to see him again. She did tell him he could not return until he completed alcohol treatment. Thus, Hal being kicked out was not indicative of an intent to permanently end the marriage relationship, it was indicative of a temporary physical separation by Wendy for the limited purpose of motivating Hal to get treatment and save the marriage. Thus the economic community would not have ended simply when he left the house.
But, after having moved out and hitting the pedestrian while drinking, Wendy learned of the accident and told Hal she wanted a divorce. At this point, both elements would be met. Hal and Wendy would have been physically separated, and one spouse has indicated an intention not to resume the marital relation by telling the other she wants a divorce.
Because the economic community did not end until that time, when Wendy told Hal she wanted a divorce, and the accident and/or the cause of action that is the basis for any judgment accrued before that time, the judgment resulting would be a community debt because it was essentially incurred before the end of the economic community. 
Debt
Debt incurred before or during the marriage can be satisfied from the community or from the tortfeasor's separate property. Debt incurred by a spouse for necessaries, including medical care, can be satisfied from community property or the separate property of either spouse, although indemnity may be available. Here, the debt is for tort judgment and, as stated above, can be satisfied from either community property or separate property of Hal, first from his separate property and then from the community property.
In California, for the purpose of debt for necessaries or medical services, end of the economic community can only occur on divorce. Judgment may not be able to be satisfied from Wendy's earnings if she kept them in a separate (versus joint) account from which Hal had no right of withdrawal.
CONCLUSION--Because the debt was incurred before end of the economic community, it is a community debt. Therefore, it can be satisfied from community property or separate property of Hal. Because the tort that is the basis of the judgment was not conducted for the benefit of the community, the judgment must be satisfied first from Hal's separate property. But because Hal has no separate property, his only asset is the house, it will be reduced to judgment and recovery sought from the asset that is the community home, which as above is classified as community property. Wendy may be able to seek indemnity.
2. Is Wendy's interest in the family home subject to payment of Hal's legal fees under California law?
As stated above, the economic community ended when Wendy kicked Hal out of the house and told him she wanted a divorce. Hal appears from the facts to have consulted the lawyer after that time. Debt incurred after the end of the economic community will belong to the debtor spouse.
Attorney Fees for Divorce Lawyer
Generally, a spouse may not unilaterally encumber community real property without a joint action on behalf of both spouses. Additionally, the spouse may not separately encumber her half interest in the property. The one exception to this rule is for the spouse to satisfy attorney fees in the divorce proceeding between the spouses.
Here, because the lawyer is not representing Hal as a family attorney in his anticipated divorce proceeding with Wendy, this rule would not apply. The lawyer fees incurred by Hal after the economic community ended for the purpose of defending against the tort suit could only be satisfied from Hal's separate property.
Division of Assets on Divorce
Generally, assets are divided pro rata at divorce, 50-50, no cashing out one spouse to give the other an entire asset. The only general exceptions to this rule are: for a closely held corporation whose shares are community assets where one spouse is the CEO and division would destroy the business; a pension plan from which one spouse can take a cashout instead of receiving payments from the pension so the spouse, who no longer wish to have any connection can go their separate ways; or, for the family home when selling it and dividing the proceeds will uproot the children and cause them harm.
While this is the family home, there appear to be no children and no reason not to apply the binding pro rata division, 50-50, by sale of the house and splitting the assets.
This means that on divorce, the assets of the house will be split evenly between the parties. Once the divorce decree is entered, the proceeds from the house that Hal receives are going to be his separate property. Upon divorce, the legal fees of Hal's lawyer can be paid by his share of the proceeds.
But the question asks whether the payment of Hal's legal fees will be satisfied from Wendy's interest in the home. Wendy has no interest in Hal's proceeds after divorce from sale of the community property house, and thus the proceeds subject Hal's interest, not hers, to liability. 
CONCLUSION--because the attorney fee debt will have been incurred after end of the economic community, it will be separate debt of Hal, and does not subject any of Wendy's interest in the family home to liability for those fees. The exception for divorce attorney fees does not apply.
3. What ethical violations has the lawyer committed according to both the ABA and California law?
A lawyer is a fiduciary of the client. She has a duty of confidentiality (not to communicate information relating to representation), a duty of loyalty not to act on behalf of her own, a client's, or a third party's best interests that are adverse to her client's, financial duties, and duties of competence which are all owed to the client.
Duty of Loyalty
Under the duty of loyalty, the lawyer must not develop an interest or maintain an interest that is adverse to the client, whether it is the interest of the lawyer herself, an interest of one of the lawyer's other clients, or an interest of a third party with whom the lawyer is closely related.
Loyalty--Financial Assistance to Clients
Under the ABA rules, a lawyer is not permitted to lend the client money for the representation, with the exception of forwarding costs of litigation to indigent clients and forwarding costs associated with a contingent fee arrangement. Under the California rules, the lawyer can lend the client any amount for any reason, as long as she does not promise to satisfy the existing debts of the client in order to buy the client's business.
Therefore, from this perspective, the loan would be considered acceptable under the California rules but unacceptable under the ABA rules. Under the ABA rules, once the client becomes indebted to the attorney, the attorney's personal interest against the client in collecting the money and receiving payment for the debt may conflict with his duty to act for the sole benefit of the client. Under the California rules, because this is not a promise to satisfy pre-existing debt for the prospective client, this is acceptable. 
Loyalty--Transacting Business or Developing Adverse Interest to Client
Whenever the lawyer enters into business with the client, the terms must be fair, the lawyer must disclose the terms (effect of the transaction) to the client in writing, allow for an opportunity for the client to consult with independent counsel and probably should suggest she do so if the lawyer's interest will be adverse to the client's in the litigation, and obtain consent from the client in writing.
This loan would essentially be such a transaction. The facts do not indicate the above elements are met. Additionally, there is a question whether it would be fair to encumber a client's sole asset in order to receive payment. But the above rules that specifically address lending a client money are going to govern whether the transaction is permissible. Regardless, even though the loan is permissible under California law, the attorney should ethically consider whether the terms of the loan are fair and suggest receiving independent legal advice if the client wishes to fund the representation in this manner.
Financial Duties
The reason the nature of the fee arrangement is important is to judge whether it is permissible for the lawyer to charge the client in this way. Under the ABA, the fee must be reasonable considering the experience of the lawyer, novelty of the case, difficulty of legal issues, time and effort required, etc. In California, it simply must not be unconscionable. The question is whether the lawyer has complied with the requirements for charging a fee, and whether the amount is justified.
Contingent Fee
A lawyer can enter into either an hourly fee arrangement or a contingent fee arrangement with a client, or potentially a flat fee arrangement. Under the ABA rules, contingent fee arrangements (lawyer forwards fees and sometimes costs in order for a stake in the recovery, if there happens to be one) are not available in criminal or domestic cases. They must include the percentage of recovery taken, the costs deducted from recovery, and whether they are deducted before or after. In California, the agreement must also indicate that it is subject to negotiation with the lawyer and what costs will not be covered by the contingent fee arrangement.
Under ABA rules, this may be a criminal case, but considering the question implies a money judgment that could subject the house to liability, brought by a private party pedestrian; using contingent fee arrangement in this case would be permissible. But here, if the mortgage is being used as payment, and thus this is more likely to be considered an hourly fee arrangement.
Hourly Fee
The agreement, under ABA rules, must disclose the rate at which the fee is charged, the services it covers, and the respective duties of lawyer and client. In California, it must also be in writing unless it is for less than $1,000, with a corporate client, routine matter for regular client, or emergency renders this impossible.
CONCLUSION--There is nothing in the facts to indicate the lawyer has complied with any of the above requirements regarding the fee arrangement. He made the offer to encumber the property without explaining the calculation of the rate, providing a writing, explaining what services it would cover, etc. Additionally, the case appears to be a simple one, involving culpability for drunk driving. Depending on how much the house was worth, a lien on the home could be unreasonable or unconscionable under either California or ABA approach.
Duty of Competence
A lawyer has a duty of competence, to represent the client with the skill, knowledge, thoroughness and preparation necessary to carry out the representation effectively. 
As stated above, the home is community property. It cannot be encumbered unless both spouses jointly enter into the transaction. The non-consenting spouse can recover the house even from a BFP, and set aside the transaction, if she has not agreed to it. There is a one year statute of limitations, but if the buyer knew the seller was married and failed to seek consent from the other spouse, there is no statute of limitations.
Here, an attempt to encumber the community property house to satisfy the separate debt of Hal would be a failure of competence on the part of the lawyer. A lawyer of reasonable skill, knowledge, thoroughness and preparation would be aware of this and would not attempt to encumber property to pay his debts knowing it was community property not subject to this type of transaction without consent of Wendy. This would ineffectively carry out the representation.
CONCLUSION--Under ABA rules only, the lawyer has breached his duty of loyalty to the client by lending him money in regard to the transaction. Although, he may argue he is permitted to do so because he is permitted to forward costs of litigation to indigent clients and Hal is indigent because he is unemployed and has no assets but the house. But because the house cannot be encumbered this way without the consent of Wendy, and a lawyer of reasonable skill and knowledge would know this, the attempt to encumber the house without Wendy's permission may also be a breach of duty of competence, subjecting the lawyer to discipline, sanctions, and malpractice liability. There is also a question of whether the amount of the fee is reasonable or unconscionable in light of the nature of the litigation and employment of the lawyer.
